comments.author: bgelens
comments.body:
Installed x64 Win10 MSI. PSVersionTable shows dirty git commit id.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10071039/18580331/4cc01dda-7bfb-11e6-865b-7d4cdef8073d.png)

comments.author: vors
comments.body:
Cc @daxian-dbw 
We may need to re-create this msi and maybe other packages.
We should add a check for that in `Starr-PSPackage`.

comments.author: daxian-dbw
comments.body: Ah, it's probably because I had to change `Get-PackageVersionAsMajorMinorBuildRevision` in build.psm1 to get the right version for the generated package.

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: Ha, it's not the first time that's happened. Since the PSVersionTable does just read from a file, you can modify powershell.version in the publish directory and overwrite the GitCommitId not have -dirty. Kind of cheating but sometimes necessary.

comments.author: daxian-dbw
comments.body: I have uploaded new `.msi` and `.zip` packages that fix the GitCommitId. But they are not digitally signed :(
